# Hi campers. We are archiving the Translators room and moving everyone over to our new [Contributors](https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors) room.

There are several reasons why we're doing this:
1. it will facilitate more cross-discipline collaboration 
2. it will give everyone a better idea of what contributors are working on
3. it will be more lively (and chat should be lively)

We will archive this public room in a few days, close it, then release the message history of this (and hundreds of other archived rooms) as open data. 

So join me over here: https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/Contributors

@christophermoura one issue that we had when translating to Spanish was that we had many options of translations for a given English term, and keeping track of the voting was a chore. I was thinking of something like the voting app in the challenges. Anyone can create a new record and add a translation candidate. Others can vote on the existing options or add a new one. The database can be searchable as a dictionary, showing the most voted translation along with the other alternatives.

@christophermoura the glossary in the wiki is outdated.  The experience with the spanish translation now is in the wiki article:

@christophermoura regarding the glossary, I think that it would be nice to compile every one of them for all languages in one single place. The glossaries are a very nice by-product of the internationalization effort and would be helpful for translators in the future. For example, the MDN Documentation is still far from being fully translated, so sharing our glossaries would make their work easier.

@vtamara I've seen that you mention in the [Recomendaciones](https://github.com/vtamara/fcc_trad/blob/master/Recomendaciones.md) document, the use of Google Translator Toolkit and a Glossary. I was also found the [Spanish Translation Terminology](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Spanish-Translation-Terminology) wiki page and realized that all translation efforts could benefit from your experience. Could you point it out some good practices that you (Spanish translators) used in your work?

By the way, in Glossary in the [Recomendaciones](https://github.com/vtamara/fcc_trad/blob/master/Recomendaciones.md), it is mentioned that "_Camper_" must be translated to "_Campista_", while in the [Spanish Translation Terminology](https://github.com/FreeCodeCamp/FreeCodeCamp/wiki/Spanish-Translation-Terminology) wiki page, the same term is, among others, in a list that should not be translated. Is it the case of a outdated document?

After translating that file with help of Google Translator Toolkit I had to incorporate the resuling translations back into the main json file, I did that with another little programa: fcc_trad/importrad.js that you can find at https://github.com/vtamara/fcc_trad/blob/master/importrad.js

Before copy/pasting I prepared a json file extracted from the original, but only with the fields id, nameEs and descriptionEs (in turkish case would be nameTr and descriptionTr). nameTr had the title in english and descriptionTr had the description in english.  For preparing this file I used a little program fcc_trad/exportad.js that you can find at: https://github.com/vtamara/fcc_trad/blob/master/exportrad.js

@jeanleonino translators don't have commit acces to the github repo of FCC.  We depend on other people with commit access.   I'm pretty sure they review the pull requests before merging.  For them it is easier to check smaller pull requests, for that reason the answers of @justinian336 and @Janainaf are what worked for the spanish team.

Yeah, as @Janainaf says, you create a branch on your fork for the specific issue you're working on, then you make the PR  to the main repository from that branch. It's advisable to never work on the staging branch of your fork.
